headline: Blueberry Sorbet
description: Smooth and ultra blueberry-y, homemade blueberry sorbet, perfect for a hot summer day.
name: Blueberry Sorbet
keywords: Freezer-friendly, Blueberry, Sorbet, American, Gluten-Free, Vegan, Dessert

nutrition.servingSize: Makes a little less than a quart

recipeIngredient: 5 cups fresh or frozen blueberries, rinsed, stems removed and discarded
Fresh blueberries and sprigs of mint for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Place the blueberries, sugar, honey, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt in a large bowl. Stir to coat blueberries with the sugar. Mash with a potato masher.
Put the mashed blueberries into a blender and blend for a couple of minutes until smooth.
Place a sieve over a large bowl and working in batches, press the mixture through the sieve, using a rubber spatula. This will catch the tougher and larger pieces of lemon and blueberry peel.

Chill the mixture for at least an hour in the fridge. Then process following the directions of your ice cream maker. Eat immediately (the sorbet will still be a little soft) or freeze at least a few hours to help firm up before eating. Eat soon after making though, as the sorbet will get progressively harder the longer it stays in the freezer. Serve with a few fresh blueberries and a sprig of mint. Links: How to make ice cream without a machine - tips from David Lebovitz

review.reviewBody:
This turned out great! I used frozen blueberries and the recommended amount of sugar and salt. I subbed agave syrup for the honey, just to see what would happen. I also added some fresh basil for complexity and a splash of Luxardo Marsachino Liqueur to keep it from freezing too solid.



I only slightly thawed the frozen berries before putting them in the blender. Before I strained it I tasted it, and it was so smooth I didn't feel the need to strain it at all. The straining is the only part of this recipe that is a pain, so if your blender is strong and you can get a smooth blend, I suggest that you don't need to strain the mixture. Mine worked out fine without it.

Sounds good but I'm not sure why you would add sugar when you've already got honey in it? Also, what's the role of salt in this recipe? Salt is a silent killer and I personally don't think it's needed in this desert. Anyways, it's down to choices. I've made this sorbet with just blueberries, honey, lemon juice and warm water and it's always so delish.
Can you recommend a way to do this without an ice cream maker? I know it's probably possible but I'm just not sure how.
If you add a small amount of vodka, 1/4 oz or so, it won't harden. It won't effect the flavor either.
Had it on a 27 celcius day, Bloody yummy and so great I didn't have to run to town for a dessert. It was a nice and light after dinner finisher.
